page.title: 14Richmond Park 3. Plantations
page.content: South of White Lodge is the Tercentenary Plantation planted in 1937 to mark the 300th anniversary of the founding of the Park and to commemorate the Coronation of George 6th who was born at White Lodge. In the plantation of trees one finds signs of three mammals to be found in the Park, the grey squirrel, the rabbit and the badger. In the Isabella Plantation, a woodland garden, there are many exotic trees, planted mostly since World War 2 ; the Metasequoia, a conifer from China; Rhododendron, Azalea, Camellia and Magnolia. This plantation is crowded with visitors on Sunday afternoons in May and June when the Azaleas are in bloom. In the Park there are many different grasses, rushes and sedges growing. (continued over)
